SENT.plain: An 18-month-old achondroplastic child presented with respiratory distress and severe pulmonary hypertension which was considered to be due to an atrial septal defect
The septal defect was closed via catheterization with Amplatzer occluder device, but the patient showed only mild to moderate clinical improvement

In addition, sleep monitoring study revealed apneas, oxygen desaturation and CO(2) retention; therefore, magnetic resonance imaging of the brain was performed, showing medullary compression by a stenotic foramen magnum
Surgical craniocervical decompression led to an improvement in sleep disturbances and pulmonary hypertension
In conclusion, several factors, among which medullary compression, may be a cause of pulmonary hypertension in achondroplasia patients
